Newsbeuter

Published on 02-12-2013 in unix
Google Reader was my news reader of choice over the last years, but it was stopped earlier this year. Alternatives were proposed or already existed, and I tried to replace the previous behaviour, which can be written as "skim through ~100 feeds daily with a simple yet feature-rich interface" (understand : keyboard shortcuts). Android sync was a plus. I tried Feedly and Digg, both with a similar interface to Google Reader (presentation, shortcuts). But they are slow. Very slow. Too slow. And it has some quirks that made me ditch them (for instance, with feedly, when in "headlines mode", I couldn't navigate the feeds without marking the article as read: if I want to keep it unread, I have to mark unread each time…). I have just tried newsbeuter. What a relief: it works like mutt, it is fast, configurable. It lacks a feature however: a "view-all-unread" and a "view all articles", because by default articles are presented ordered under a feed hierarchy. But, as Newsbeuter is really configurable, it can be added. Yay! I just added two "query-feeds": "query:Unread Articles:unread = \"yes\"" "query:Articles:author =~ ".*"" The first one is at the top of my list of feeds, the second at the bottom (I use it less often).
